bibl.title: Letter from Robert Carter to Robert Burridge, 1718 June 27

div1.p: Robert Carter writes to Robert Burridge, a merchant in Lyme Regis, Dorset, England, on June 27, 1718, reporting a draft on Burridge to John Parker, and reminding Burridge that he had asked Carter to buy some tobacco for him. Now he has written to Carter complaining about the high prices in Virginia for tobacco, and Carter notes "Indeed there hath been no such time produced the like within my memory." The Scots merchants are buying up "most ordinary, meanest stuff in the country " at these extraordinary prices. Carter continues that he has not had the opportunity of shipping tobacco to Burridge this year but will next if a Lyme ship presents itself. He asks Burridge to pressure his brother John (a London merchant and member of Parliament) to account to Carter for 9 hogheads sent him 2 years earlier. He concludes that Burridge complains at length about Daniel McCarty who, in turn, complains about Burridge. He does not know where the truth is, but hopes "you may be so much friends to your own peace to compromise your differences among yourselves," and counsels that the only ones who gain in lawsuits are the lawyers.

div1.head: Letter from Robert Carter to Robert Burridge, June 27, 1718

opener.dateline:
[Corotoman, Lancaster County, Virginia]
June 27th 1718.
To Robert Burridge

div1.p:
My last advised you of a draft
I had made on you to John Parker for
£50. In one of your's this year you
advise me to purchase you some Tobo
upon bills. In another you controul
yourself upon the news you had of the
high prices given here. Indeed there
hath been no such time produced
the like within my memory. 21,
22, 23, 24 & 25 p Ct hath been
given this year for Tobo. The most
ordinary, meanest stuff in the country
hath sold at these prices and the
Scotch are still laying up all the refuse
and trash they can meet with. what the
misterie of their trade is I don't
know; but sure I am were we to give
these prices for such goods we should
never see our principal by a great deal.

No freight this year within my
reach hath offered to your Port.
You must not thence conclude
I have done with sending Tobo.
thither. Next year, God willing,
I intend to be at it again upon
the first freight I meet with.

Your brother John, the Paria=
ment man, stands in my debt for
nine Hhds of Tobo I sent him two
years ago—would never yet let me
know what he sold it for. I am
very sorry there is such a flaw in
the reputation of one of your family.
Methinks you should be so much
concerned at it as to attempt everything
in your power to bring him into the
humour of doing me justice: and
pray interest yourself so much at
least in my behalf to get an accot
what is become of my goods. I
find 'tis in vain for me to write
to him. You'll do your family but
a credit to bestir yourself so
effectually that I may have my money.

I find Capt. [Daniel] McCarty and you
can by no means set your horses
together. You complain mightily
against him and he is as big with
complaints of you. Who is in the
wrong I can't tell. One story is
always good till another is heard.
I wish you may be so much
friends to your own peace to
compromise your differences among
yourselves. Few get so much in the
end in going into contentions of
Law, set aside the Lawyers and
Officers. But this is none of my
business.

div1.head: NOTES
div1.note: Source copy consulted: Minor- Blackford Papers, James Monroe Law Office and Museum, Fredericksburg, Virginia. These texts are all nineteenth-century copies. Apparently there was in existence a letter book of Robert Carter's—now lost—from which the unknown copyist recorded these texts. As they are the only texts, the punctuation and "corrections" obviously supplied by the copyist have been retained.

Robert Carter generally used a return address of "Rappahannock" for the river on which he lived rather than "Corotoman," the name of his home, on his correspondence, especially to merchants abroad. The return address, county, and colony have been added for clarity to this unheaded letter.
[2] Burridge was located in Lyme Regis, Dorset.

[3] John Burridge (1681?-1753), brother of Robert, was a merchant in London trading primarily "to Guinea and the West Indies." It is not surprising that RC could not obtain the sales report and money he mentions in this letter; in 1717, John Burridge's estate had been seized by the Crown for non-payment of duties on wine. John Burridge represented Lyme in Parliament from 1710-1728. (Sedgwick. The History of Parliament . . . Commons. I, 509.)
